The user has 98 answers and, you've guessed it, they are all created with GPT.
PLOT TWIST: The questions where also created with GPT!

I've been reading and re-reading @robin's post, "The Internet Transition," for days now, and it's stupendous.

It matches and extends every intuition I've had about this new world we're in, and puts it all to words in a seemingly effortless way. I know how much effort it took, because it's the post I've always wished I could have written on the topic. Anyone who cares about governance or structures in our complicated new world should absolutely give it a go.

https://berjon.com/internet-transition/#fn-12

Here's the first iteration of the syllabus for this semester's " Introduction to Digital Humanities
Part II: Computational Approaches to Culture." Surprised that there aren't too many TBAs. You may find a few things of interest:

a) The final paper will be co-written with AI.
b) There's a midterm exam whose sole purpose in life is to use it as a tool to build vocab and understanding.
c) I set up a binary between Analysis and Poesis that, spoiler alert, I will undermine during the semester.
d) I barely teach coding. Instead I spend a lot of teaching energy on how to read tutorials and corpus analysis papers.

Tagging @laurenfklein and @zoeleblanc who are going on a similar journey this semester too.

http://teaching.elotroalex.com/s23-intro-dh/

British Rail was the state-owned company which ran the UK's railway network from 1948 to 1997. It didn't do anything else, just trains and public transport.

Inexplicably, in 1973 it patented a nuclear fusion-powered flying saucer with an artificial gravity generator, creating a graviton field using high energy electrons.

Here's the patent:

https://worldwide.espacenet.com/patent/search?q=pn%3DGB1310990

Here's an in-depth look at the whole bizarre situation:

https://allthatsinteresting.com/british-rail-flying-saucer

title: The Lisa: Apple's Most Influential Failure - CHM

last_post.content:
The Computer History Museum in Mountain View has worked with Apple to secure the release of the source code for the OS and office applications of the #AppleLisa computer.

Arguably, this is the earliest comprehensive #GUI environment for a personal computer, and it was first for sale 40 years ago today. It was written in a whole lot of #Pascal .

You can download it here:

https://computerhistory.org/blog/the-lisa-apples-most-influential-failure/

Meanwhile, on LisaList2, folks are starting to dig in:

https://lisalist2.com/index.php/topic,351.0.html

title: Chapter 2 Error control | Improving Your Statistical Inferences

last_post.content: If you repeatedly perform a hypothesis test when the null hypothesis is true, p-values will randomly drift between 0 and 1, and therefore, if you test often enough, you will always find a significant effect. https://lakens.github.io/statistical_inferences/errorcontrol.html#optionalstopping This is why preregistration is important. You can test multiple times as data comes in, but then you need to adjust the alpha level: https://lakens.github.io/statistical_inferences/sequential.html For a single simulation of the p-values you could get, see:

title: Bringing informative priors into your experiment: Bayesian impact evaluation

last_post.content: For a long time I've wanted to try out Bayesian impact evaluation, by formally eliciting priors from policymakers, academics, and program recipients, and then incorporating these into the analysis. A new working paper with Rachael Meager and Leo Iacovone details how we did this with an export promotion program in Colombia, and shows when this gives similar results to frequentist analysis, and where it adds value. A blog summary (and link to the paper) is now up: https://blogs.worldbank.org/impactevaluations/bringing-informative-priors-your-experiment-bayesian-impact-evaluation

TIL about the "Zero one infinity" rule from a post by @estark.

This definitely comes up often in standard library design and security decisions: if you can't argue why a cutoff should be at a specific value, it might not make sense to have the cutoff. Workloads and machines are so varied, that there is no one-size-fit-all.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero_one_infinity_rule

title: New features in dplyr 1.1.0, and an introduction to ivs

last_post.content:
dplyr 1.1.0 is coming very soon!

I recently spoke about it (and the ivs 📦) at the Charlotte #rstats User Group. This presentation highlights a number of exciting new features, including:

- Per-operation grouping with `.by`
- Join enhancements, like inequality joins, rolling joins, and overlap joins
- New functions like `consecutive_id()` and `case_match()`

title: The Case of the Golden Idol

last_post.content:
If you liked Return of the Obra Dinn, and especially if you were into it but it was maybe a little too much detective work for you to keep track of, I highly highly recommend The Case of the Golden Idol. It's a detective game where you investigate crime scenes and try to reconstruct what happened, similar to Obra Dinn's filling out of the ship manifest through inference. But the puzzles are a little smaller scope, and it's all 2D. It is SO GOOD.

https://www.thegoldenidol.com/

I started playing with a new (to me) series of tooltip interactions in a hex map in my latest story for USAFacts.

You can trigger the tooltip on big screens by hovering with your mouse or accessing the map with your "TAB" key and then using arrow keys to navigate individual states.

On small screens, hitboxes are small, so I opted to trigger tooltips via a slider which lists states in alphabetical order.

title: Creating A Log-Analysis System To Autodetect and Announce Mastodon Scr

last_post.content:
New #blog: Autodetecting and Announcing #Mastodon Scrapers and Crawlers

There've been quite a few #fedisearch issues recently, but the common thread is that there's usually a gap in reporting - they're often live for weeks before people are made aware.

It's not just people's pet projects either, there are other #scrapers active, quietly consuming posts

So, I built a bot to detect and out them so that fedi admins can block as necessary

https://www.bentasker.co.uk/posts/blog/security/autodetecting-and-outing-mastodon-scrapers-with-scrapersnitchbot.html

#infosec #security

title: The Secret To Learning More Complex Chords

last_post.content:
In her latest video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S21TYlzbxYc

Aimee Nolte shows us some ways we can stack a triad on top of the dominant 7th chord

1 3 5 ♭7

She plays this chord in C so it's called C7. The 5th is so obvious and bland she often leaves it out, giving what's called a 'shell voicing'

1 3 ♭7

Then she puts a triad on top of this, giving 'upper structures' like a 9th, 11th or 13th.

This is right at my level now, so I like it. Let me say a bit about it.

(1/n)

title: Spotlight Tweets: A Lens for Exploring Attention Dynamics within Online Sensemaking during Crisis Events | ACM Transactions on Social Computing

last_post.content:
Excited for the publications of our paper (w/ Kaitlyn Zhou and Emma Spiro): Spotlight Tweets: A Lens for Exploring Attention Dynamics within Online Sensemaking during Crisis Events. The paper, which looks at sensemaking during the 2018 Hawaii missile crisis, makes several contributions, including: presenting the concept of “spotlighting” and introducing our cumulative graph technique, which reveals how audience exposure affects the propagation of social media posts.
https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3577213

The Computer History Museum in Mountain View has worked with Apple to secure the release of the source code for the OS and office applications of the #AppleLisa computer.

Arguably, this is the earliest comprehensive #GUI environment for a personal computer, and it was first for sale 40 years ago today. It was written in a whole lot of #Pascal .

You can download it here:

https://computerhistory.org/blog/the-lisa-apples-most-influential-failure/

Meanwhile, on LisaList2, folks are starting to dig in:

https://lisalist2.com/index.php/topic,351.0.html
